title: One-step CRISPR-Cas9 protocol for the generation of plug and play conditional knockouts in Drosophila melanogaster

sgRNA cloning
Timing: 3–4 days
The protocol for cloning sgRNAs into the pCFD4 vector is according to (Port et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]), which can be found at http://www.crisprflydesign.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Cloning-with-pCFD4.pdf[href=http://www.crisprflydesign.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Cloning-with-pCFD4.pdf]. The protocol for the alternative pCFD5 vector can be found at http://www.crisprflydesign.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/pCFD5cloningprotocol.pdf[href=http://www.crisprflydesign.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/pCFD5cloningprotocol.pdf].
Using pCFD4 vector as a template, run a PCR with the primers from Before you begin step 6
Set up the following PCR reaction mix

Run the PCR by referring to the conditions from Before you begin step 5e. The optimal annealing temperature is 61°C.
Digest pCFD4 vector with BbsI-HF at 37°C for 1 h, according to the following reaction mix.
table:files/protocols_protocol_679_6.csv
Run PCR product and digested vector on 1% agarose gel.
PCR product size: 600bp
Digested vector size: 6.4 kb
Gel purify the PCR product and the digested vector with the QIAquick Gel Extraction Kit, according to the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.qiagen.com/gb/resources/resourcedetail?id=a72e2c07-7816-436f-b920-98a0ede5159a&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/gb/resources/resourcedetail?id=a72e2c07-7816-436f-b920-98a0ede5159a&lang=en]).
Insert the PCR product into the linearized vector using Gibson Assembly (NEB) according to the manufacturer’s instructions (https://international.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/11/gibson-assembly-protocol-e5510[href=https://international.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/11/gibson-assembly-protocol-e5510]).
Transform with competent bacteria and plate on Ampicillin LB agar plates. The final concentration of Ampicillin is 100 μg/mL.
Pick a few individual colonies and culture 16 h for MiniPrep (Qiagen) the following day, following the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=331740ca-077f-4ddd-9e5a-2083f98eebd5&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=331740ca-077f-4ddd-9e5a-2083f98eebd5&lang=en]).

Primer for verification: GACACAGCGCGTACGTCCTTCG
Purify the pCFD4 plasmid with a Maxiprep kit (Invitrogen) following the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fpurelink_hipure_plasmid_qrc.pdf&title=UXVpY2sgUmVmZXJlbmNlOiBQdXJlTGluayBIaVB1cmUgUGxhc21pZCBETkEgUHVyaWZpY2F0aW9uIEtpdHM=[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fpurelink_hipure_plasmid_qrc.pdf&title=UXVpY2sgUmVmZXJlbmNlOiBQdXJlTGluayBIaVB1cmUgUGxhc21pZCBETkEgUHVyaWZpY2F0aW9uIEtpd]).
Pause Point: the pCFD4 plasmid can be stored at −20°C for an extended period until injection.
Repair plasmid cloning
Timing: ∼ 1 week
Components (5′ arm, region flanked by FRT sites, and 3′ arm) to be inserted into the parent repair vector pTVGFP are PCR amplified from genomic DNA extracted from the selected Cas9 line (Before you begin step 5).
Inserting 3′ homology arm into MCS2:

PCR amplify the fragment using primers designed from Before you begin step 7c. Refer to Before you begin step 5d for PCR reaction mix, and Before you begin step 5e for PCR condition. Gel purify the PCR product (refer to Before you begin step 5f).
Digest pTVGFP and the PCR product with the two restriction enzymes selected in Before you begin step 7b, setting up the following reaction mix for digesting the pTVGFP and the PCR product respectively. The reaction conditions required for the selected restriction enzymes can be found using the NEB Double Digest Finder (http://nebcloner.neb.com/[href=http://nebcloner.neb.com/]). Ligate the digested pTVGFP backbone and the PCR product, following the manufacturer’s protocol for T4 DNA Ligase (NEB) for reaction mix and conditions (https://international.neb.com/protocols/0001/01/01/dna-ligation-with-t4-dna-ligase-m0202[href=https://international.neb.com/protocols/0001/01/01/dna-ligation-with-t4-dna-ligase-m0202]). This produces the pTVGFP-3′arm vector.
Transform with competent bacteria and plate on Ampicillin plates.
Pick a few individual colonies and culture overnight for MiniPrep (Qiagen).
Verify insertion by sequencing with the following primers:
pTVGFP 3′arm forward primer for verification: GTTGTGGTTTGTCCAAACTCAT
pTVGFP 3′arm reverse primer for verification: CCATGATTACGCCAAGC
Inserting 5′ homology arm and FRT cassette into MCS1:
PCR amplify the fragments using primers designed from Before you begin step 7c. Refer to Before you begin step 5d for PCR reaction mix, and Before you begin step 5e for PCR condition. Gel purify the PCR product (refer to Before you begin step 5f).

Digest pTVGFP-3′arm with the two restriction enzymes selected in Before you begin step 8b, referring to step 10b for reaction mix and condition.
Assemble using Gibson assembly according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://international.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/11/gibson-assembly-protocol-e5510[href=https://international.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/11/gibson-assembly-protocol-e5510]), with the digested pTVGFP-3′arm as the backbone and the two PCR products in step 10a as inserts. This generates the pTVFRT-GFP donor plasmid (see troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Transform with competent bacteria and plate on Ampicillin plates.
Pick a few individual colonies and culture overnight for MiniPrep (Qiagen).
Verify insertion by sequencing with the following primers:
pTVGFP 5′arm forward primer for verification: CAGTCACGACGTTGTAAAACGA
pTVGFP Pax reverse primer for verification: GAATTAGCTCTAATTGAATTAGTCTCTAATTGAATT
Note: Steps 10 and 11 can be swapped around, depending on the availability of unique restriction sites
Note: Instead of Gibson assembly, the components can be sequentially cloned into the repair vector using restriction sites from MCS1 via ligation (see troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Purify the pTVFRT-GFP plasmid with a Maxiprep kit (Invitrogen).
Pause Point: the pTVFRT-GFP plasmid can be stored at −20°C for an extended period until injection.
Injection and screening
Timing: ∼2 weeks
The gRNA vector pCFD4 can be co-injected with the pTVFRT-GFP repair plasmid into embryos of any transgenic line that express Cas9 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A). If in-house injection facilities are not available, the injection mix can be sent to companies for injection into commonly available Cas9 lines.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/679-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Generation of the DWnt4[cKO] line and possible subsequent steps
(A) Crossing scheme after injection to establish the DWnt4[cKO] line.
(B) Diagram of the steps to generate a conditional allele of DWnt4, showing replacement of the sequence between the two target sites with FRT-flanked rescue DNA and the excisable pax-GFP cassette. For the verification of correct insertion, the binding location of two pairs of primers (1 and 2, 3 and 4) are shown.

(C) Examples of reintegration vectors, for subsequent introduction of DNA fragments into the locus via the attP site using PhiC31-mediated integration (Baena-Lopez et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Expand the Cas9-expressing strain to be used for injection
The injection mix contains the pCFD4 and the pTVFRT-GFP plasmids in ddH2O.
Note: Plasmid concentrations can vary. Recommended concentrations are 100 ng/μL for pCFD4 and 500 ng/μL for pTVFRT-GFP, for injecting into 300–400 embryos. Injection volume is typically less than 5% of the egg volume.
Note: Recommended amounts of each plasmid are 300 μg for pCFD4 and 500 μg for pTVFRT-GFP, for injecting into 300–400 embryos.
Timing: 1–2 months
Injected embryos are grown to adulthood and crossed to w1118 flies. Screen for GFP signal in the next generation larval CNS or the adult eyes/ocelli (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
Select individual transformants and establish balanced GFP-positive transformant lines (see troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
Extract gDNA from transformant lines and PCR verify the insertion is in the correct location. Design two sets of primers for the PCR verification, such that one of each set binds just outside the regions that correspond to the 5′ and 3′ arms, and the other binds to the GFP coding sequence (primers 1–4 in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B). For PCR reaction mixture and PCR conditions, refer to Before you begin steps 5d-e.
Optional: The pax-GFP flanked by loxP sites can be excised through Cre expression (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B). This can improve expression of the integrated fragment. Cre recombinase lines such as BL#766 and BL#851 from the Bloomington stock centre can be used.

Optional: Reintegration vectors can be introduced via the attP site via another round of injection. Examples include, introducing a GAL4 coding sequence into the locus, or reintroducing the CDS of the gene of interest but with a HA-tagged inserted within the CDS (Baena-Lopez et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1], Poernbacher et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]). (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C) Alternatively, instead of creating a conditional knockout, the re-integration vector can introduce another FRT cassette containing a mutant or tagged form of the gene of interest, thus generating a conditional switch allele. Details of the crossing scheme for the PhiC31-mediated reintegration can be found at (Hoppe and Ashe, 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
